INI211H1-F-20205.courseDescription: This introductory course focuses on the process and craft of creative writing. Students will study short fiction, creative nonfiction and poetry by established writers, and learn to respond to works-in-progress by their peers. A variety of activities will help students generate, develop, and revise a portfolio of original creative work.
INI211H1-F-20205.webTimetableInstructions:
This is a hybrid course. Lectures and writing workshops are synchronous. Discussions of reading are asynchronous. 
Lectures and writing workshops will take place during the listed class time, Tuesday 1:00pm - 4:00pm and Thursday 1:00pm - 4:00pm, via video conference using Blackboard Collaborate through Quercus. Students will also need a Zoom account using their U of T email address. Students who cannot use Zoom and students who have accessibility needs should contact the instructor for accommodations.

INI300H1-F-20205.courseTitle: Strategic Writing in Business and the Professions: Theory and Practice
INI300H1-F-20205.courseDescription: Aims to teach students to recognize the rhetoric of the professional workplace and to communicate strategically and ethically using written and oral discourse appropriate to business, government, and not-for-profit organizations. Case study analysis using ethical reasoning models is a central component of the course.
INI300H1-F-20205.webTimetableInstructions:
This is an online, asynchronous, fast-paced 6 week course. Lectures and tutorial exercises will be made available via online videos each Sunday. Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online webinar class 2 hours/week (Tuesday, 12:00 √ê 1:00 p.m. and Thursday, 12:00 -1:00 p.m. to discuss the assigned exercises). Students need PowerPoint and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra). 
Please note: students are strongly encouraged to join the synchronous online webinar classes from 12:00-1:00 p.m. on Tuesdays and Thursdays respectfully; questions regarding tutorial work will not be taken up on an individual Q & A email basis; please join the class discussion.
Synchronous online class may not be scheduled each week. Please refer to the syllabus for more information.

INI337H1-F-20205.courseDescription: This course will focus on an examination of the immediate difficulties facing Toronto and by extension all Canadian cities. Instruction will consist of a combination of lectures by the instructor and by noted experts/practitioners in a range of topic areas including urban governance, finance, planning, environmental sustainability and social welfare.
INI337H1-F-20205.webTimetableInstructions:
Course Description for 2020 Summer: As we experience the reconfiguration of life as a result of the COVID-19 global pandemic, understanding the connections between health and urban life is as important as ever. Through an interactive seminar format, this course will take a critical interdisciplinary approach to examining the intimate connections between urbanization and health.
This is an online, synchronous course. Lectures and facilitated discussion will take place as a webinar 4 hours a week (Tuesday and Thursday 2-4pm). Students need Power Point, a webcam and the ability to use videoconferencing software (free to download).

LEC-9901.subtitle: Cities and Health
LEC-9901.meetingStatusNotes:
Course Added: April 6, 2020.
Online Synchronous- See Timetable Instructions

INI409H1-S-20205.courseTitle: Special Topics in Writing and Rhetoric
INI409H1-S-20205.courseDescription: Seminars in special topics designed for students who are completing the Minor Program in Writing and Rhetoric.
INI409H1-S-20205.webTimetableInstructions:
*Prerequisite waived for 2020 Summer: permission of the instructor is not required* 

Course description for 2020 Summer: Good writing happens only through revision. But before you can revise, you need to see your writing afresh. How can you escape the "intractable subjectivity" (Joseph Williams) of composition? How can you communicate your ideas more compellingly? INI 409 teaches ways to understand this essential stage of the writing process. It investigates different steps in self-editing: detaching from a first draft, reviewing it on different levels, identifying possible issues, and strengthening weak spots. We will draw on professional editorial strategies and time-tested writing advice to help us analyze both content and expression. Writers in different genres (scholarship, journalism, fiction) will visit the class to share their revision strategies. Each student will need a piece of writing to work on, one that the student wants to improve. It could be an academic essay or a science report from an earlier term, a short story or a piece of creative nonfiction, a newspaper article, or a personal statement for post-graduate applications. Course assignments will include applying revision strategies to this text. 

This is an online hybrid course. Lectures will take place on Tuesdays and Thursdays (1:00 to 4:00 p.m.) synchronously through video conferencing. Office hours (to be confirmed) will also take place in real time. Outside classes, students will contribute to asynchronous discussions and work in groups or pairs. Students will need the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

INI432H1-F-20205.courseDescription: Special topics courses are offered periodically for senior students in the Urban Studies Program. Offerings in any given year will depend on program priorities, availability of specialized expertise and funding. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
INI432H1-F-20205.prerequisite: Enrolment in a major or specialist program in Urban Studies.
INI432H1-F-20205.recommendedPreparation: INI235H1 and INI236H1, completion of research design and research methods courses, 14 FCEs in an aligned social science program.
INI432H1-F-20205.webTimetableInstructions: **Pre-Requisites will be waived for Summer 2020; students from associated disciplines are encouraged to enrol** Course Description for 2020 Summer: This course will provide a broad overview of the roles of both the citizen and the professional practitioner in advancing effective and meaningful public participation in the policy-making process, particularly as it relates to city planning. Through an examination of a mix of theoretical frameworks and case studies from Toronto and elsewhere, you will gain an understanding of the ways in which effective public participation can contribute to the maintenance of a healthy democratic society while also exploring some of the key challenges and opportunities faced by public participation practitioners today. The course has two key objectives: to give you a practical understanding of all of the elements of an effective public participation process, and to explore how public participation processes can be designed to be more inclusive and effective. In addition, students will be able to apply this knowledge towards the development of a project or report for a client. You can read more about the course and examples of previous community engagement projects on the U of T News article regarding Rail Deck Park . This is an online asynchronous course. Lectures and tutorials will be given through online videos accessible through Quercus. Students will have the opportunity to participate in occasional synchronous online webinar classes featuring guest speakers, and to ask questions and clarifications about lecture content and assignments.

LEC-5101.subtitle: Urban Studio: Public Participation in Policy Making
